review.title: Learning Graph Topological Features via GAN
review.abstract: Inspired by the generation power of generative adversarial networks (GANs) in image domains, we introduce a novel hierarchical architecture for learning characteristic topological features from a single arbitrary input graph via GANs. The hierarchical architecture consisting of multiple GANs preserves both local and global topological features and automatically partitions the input graph into representative stages for feature learning. The stages facilitate reconstruction and can be used as indicators of the importance of the associated topological structures. Experiments show that our method produces subgraphs retaining a wide range of topological features, even in early reconstruction stages (unlike a single GAN, which cannot easily identify such features, let alone reconstruct the original graph). This paper is firstline research on combining the use of GANs and graph topological analysis.

metadata.title: Learning Graph Topological Features via GAN

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text: With the rise of social networks and the importance of the relational properties of the phenomenon of "big data," it has become increasingly important to develop ways to identify the key structures present in diagram data. However, identifying such structures is crucial to understand how a social network is shaping, or to make predictions about future network behavior. To this end, a large number of diagram analysis methods have been proposed to analyze the topology of the target network at the node (Muppidi and Koraganji 2016), community (Fortunato 2010), Martí ́ nez, Berzal, and Cubero 2016), and global levels (Wu et al. 2017), and perform certain tasks.Unfortunately, each level of analysis is strongly influenced by network topology, and so far no algorithms can be effectively adapted to work for arbitrary network structures.

sections.heading: Method
sections.text: This year, we are not dealing with such a case, but with such a case, in which such a case occurs.

sections.heading: Related Work
sections.text: The development of deep learning and the growing maturity of graph topology analysis have led to more attention being paid to the ability to use the former for the latter (Li et al. 2015), and a number of supervised and semi-supervised learning methods have been developed for graph analysis, with a particular focus on the use of CNNs (Bruna et al. 2014; Henaff, Bruna, and LeCun 2015; Duvenaud et al. 2015; Defferrard, Bresson, and Vandergheynst 2016), which have shown promising results compared to traditional graph analysis methods (such as kernel-based methods, graph-based regulation techniques, etc.). Kipf et al. has discussed the above methods in detail (Defferrard, Bresson, and Vandergheynst 2016; Kipf and Welling 2016), highlighting the strengths and drawbacks of the different approaches.

sections.heading: Evaluation
sections.text: In fact, it is as if most of them are a mere mesh in which they see themselves able to move, to move and to move. (...) It is as if they were able to move. (...) It is as if they were able to move. (...) It is as if they were able to move. (...) It is as if they were able to move. (...) It is as if they were able to move. (...) It is as if they were able to take themselves into their own hands. (...) It is as if they were able to move. (...)

sections.heading: Discussion and Future Work
sections.text: This work aims to leverage the success of GANs in (unattended) image generation to address a fundamental challenge in graph topology analysis: a model agnostic approach to learning graphical topological features. By using a GAN for each hierarchical level of the graph, we can reconstruct input diagrams very well, preserving both local and global topological features. In addition, our method is able to automatically determine the number of phases required to not parametrically reconstruct phases and the graph itself, which is potentially beneficial for understanding different phases of graph reconstruction. Our experimental results show promising results in terms of GTI's ability to learn different topological features from different graphs. To our knowledge, there is no single graph model that can capture these different topological features.
